Arsenal rescue draw against Bayern
Could Arsenal have nicked a win at the death?
Bukayo Saka was denied a late penalty after Arsenal had fought back with a Leandro Trossard goal.
The England international opened the scoring, allowing the ball to roll across him after a lovely pass from Ben White, but Bayern drew level thanks to a Serge Gnabry goal and then went ahead through a Harry Kane penalty.
So, with this tie perfectly poised ahead of next week’s second leg in Bavaria, allow The Athletic to dissect the key talking points…
Man City and Real Madrid share thrilling draw
Is there a better tie in Champions League football than Real Madrid vs Manchester City? Recent history suggests not after these two European powerhouses played out a spectacular 3-3 draw at the Santiago Bernabeu.
Meeting in the knockout stages for the third time in as many seasons, the second leg of this quarter-final back in Manchester surely can’t come quickly enough after the two teams shared six goals in a truly memorable encounter.
After Bernardo Silva had given City an early lead, Eduardo Camavinga and Rodrygo struck to put Madrid 2-1 up. Spectacular goals from Phil Foden and Josko Gvardiol turned the game on its head before Federico Valverde had the final say to round things off.
Dermot Corrigan, Sam Lee and Mark Carey break down the main talking points from an unforgettable match.
Full-time in Champions League
A frankly ludicrous night of Champions League football has — sadly – come to an end.
Real Madrid and Manchester City shared six goals in a thrilling, back and forth contest with Phil Foden, Josko Gvardiol and Fede Valverde all netting brilliant strikes.
Over in north London, it was also honours even as Leandro Trossard equalised late on to ensure it will be all square when Arsenal and Bayern meet again next week.
- Arsenal 2-2 Bayern Munich
- Real Madrid 3-3 Manchester City
Thought of England return got me through ACL recovery - Williamson
Leah Williamson says the thought of an England comeback helped get her through her recovery from an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.
The central defender, 27, made her first appearance for her country in 364 days against the Republic of Ireland in Dublin, having torn her ACL playing for Arsenal 12 months ago.
She was forced to miss the World Cup in Australia and New Zealand — where Sarina Wiegman's European champions went on to reach the final.
Asked what got her through her rehabilitation, she replied: "This. I had my eyes set on this. These days with ACLs, you come back hopefully in a healthy way but I wanted to be good enough to play for England again.
"The standards are so high and the players that have been here have made them higher. This was the thought and I felt today was a completion of that journey."
Goals from Lauren James and Alex Greenwood saw England through to what could prove to be an important three points in Euro 2025 qualifying.
They now sit second in Group A3 behind leaders France, who have won two from two.
Asked how much she enjoyed being back, Williamson said: "Honestly, I just really, really love playing for England.
"When I put this badge on, I feel 10 times taller, 10 times stronger. I don't know. The girls are such a great group of girls and I loved every second of that."
England are next in action when they face England at St James' Park on May 31.
England beat Republic of Ireland in Euro 2025 qualifier
England have beaten the Republic of Ireland in their Euro 2025 qualifier in Dublin.
First-half goals from Lauren James and Alex Greenwood were enough to earn a 2-0 victory for Sarina Wiegman's side.
The win moves them on to four points from two fixtures in Group A3. Ireland are bottom of the group without a point so far.
France lead the way after they beat Sweden in tonight's other game.
Half-time in the Champions League
It's lived up to the hype with six goals already in the two Champions League quarter-finals so far.
Harry Kane has got one of them to give Bayern the lead over Arsenal. It's his sixth at Emirates Stadium — a record for any visiting player.
- Arsenal 1-2 Bayern Munich
- Real Madrid 2-1 Manchester City
England lead Republic of Ireland
Lauren James and Alex Greenwood have put England ahead against the Republic of Ireland at half-time in Dublin.
James fired in early before Greenwood slotted home from the penalty spot to double the advantage for Sarina Wiegman's side.
Greenwood later erred when presented a second opportunity from 12 yards but England are still in complete control at the break.
France have beaten Sweden 1-0 in the other game in this group to leave them top with a maximum six points so far.
Follow the Champions League
What a night of Champions League football we have in store.
Arsenal host Bayern Munich in the first leg of their quarter-final with Harry Kane returning to renew is rivalry with the Gunners.
Over in Spain, it's a renewal of another rivalry with 14-time winners Real Madrid hosting defending champions Manchester City.
You can follow both of those on The Athletic with dedicated live blogs manned by experts in north London and Madrid.
Arsenal vs Bayern is here while City's trip to Real is here.
Infantino addresses MLS owners’ meeting
FIFA president Gianni Infantino addressed MLS owners in person at the league’s board of governors meeting today in Los Angeles, becoming the first FIFA president to attend the league’s board meeting since MLS’s founding in 1996.
“I was very happy for the first time that the FIFA president comes to an MLS meeting of this nature,” Infantino told The Athletic.
“We have great events coming up here in North America with the new Club World Cup next year, the World Cup in ‘26, so a lot of promotion for soccer, or football as we call it.”
The MLS board of governors consists of a representative from ownership of each of the league’s 30 teams and is led by commissioner Don Garber.
The board meets in person three times per year and often uses those meetings to discuss league business and vote on league initiatives.
Williamson, Hampton, Toone, Park start for England
Leah Williamson is starting her first England game for nearly a year in the Euro 2025 qualifier against the Republic of Ireland tonight.
The 27-year-old has not featured for the Lionesses since suffering an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury in April 2023, which forced her to miss last summer’s World Cup.
She was an unused substitute in the 1-1 draw against Sweden on Friday but starts and captains the side in Dublin.
Elsewhere, Hannah Hampton starts in goal in place of Mary Earps while Jess Carter comes in for Chelsea team-mate Niamh Charles.
Man City's Jess Park gets the nod in midfield while there is also a start for Ella Toone.
Sweden host France in the other game in the group. It's 0-0 at half-time.
Koundé wary of threat from France teammates Mbappe and Dembélé
Jules Koundé says stopping his France international teammates Kylian Mbappe and Ousmane Dembélé could be the key to Barcelona overcoming Paris Saint-Germain in the last eight of the Champions League.
Barcelona — five-time winners of the competition — take on PSG in the first leg of their quarter-final tie at the Parc des Princes on Wednesday.
Speaking on the prospect of facing off against his countrymen, Koundé said: "They are great players who have the ability to eliminate opponents. Both Ousmane and Mbappe are difference makers."
Mbappe — who becomes a free agent in the summer — played a starring role in the most recent meeting between the two sides in 2021, scoring four goals across the two legs of their last-16 tie to book PSG's place in the quarter-finals.
"I know him well because we played together in France, he's a player who makes the difference," Koundé added on Mbappe's threat. "We'll try to stop him on a collective level, (but) they are much more than just one player."
Koundé has made 38 appearances for the Blaugrana in all competitions this season, including six in the Champions League. He has won 26 caps for his country since making his debut in June 2021.
Barcelona host PSG a six days later in the return leg. The winner of the tie will face either Atletico Madrid or Borussia Dortmund in the semi-finals.
Xavi: I have a great relationship with Luis Enrique
Xavi says he has a “great relationship” with Luis Enrique after the Paris Saint-Germain head coach had earlier said his style of football embodies Barcelona better than former midfielder’s current side.
The two teams meet each other in the first leg of their Champions League quarter-final tie on Wednesday.
Luis Enrique spent eight years at Barcelona as a player and a further three as manager winning the La Liga title and the Champions League during his first year in charge, in what was Xavi’s final season as a Barca player.
He won eight major trophies after taking the managerial post in 2014 playing an attacking, fluid and possession-based style of football.
Asked who represents Barcelona's style best out of the two of them as coaches, Luis Enrique replied: "Me, without any doubt. Look at the data, in possession of the ball, in scoring chances, in high pressing...
"Look at the titles, the trophies. It's not an opinion, it's data. Without any doubt, me! Others may have a different opinion".
Xavi, who himself won the league title in his first full season in charge of the club, attempted to play down talk of oneupmanship ahead of the game at the Parc des Princes.
Man Utd Women offer manager Skinner new contract
Manchester United Women have offered manager Marc Skinner a new contract.
Terms have not yet been agreed but both parties are continuing to talk and are keen to come to an agreement with Skinner’s existing deal expiring at the end of this season.
This is United’s second move to address the women’s team since new part-owners INEOS took control of the club’s football operations after purchasing a minority stake in the from the Glazer family for $1.3bn, following the appointment of Matt Johnson as their new head of women’s football on an interim basis last month.
The decision to offer Skinner an extension was made by United's incumbent football leadership along with oversight from INEOS.
Sir Dave Brailsford, INEOS' sporting director, has been working at United since February, while Andy O’Boyle, United's deputy director of football since May 2022, already oversees the women's side as part of his duties and will continue to do so alongside Johnson.
John Murtough had worked as United's football director, a role which included the women’s team, but he is leaving the club this week after more than 10 years in Manchester.

Hinshelwood signs new Brighton contract through to 2028
Jack Hinshelwood has signed a new contract with Brighton & Hove Albion that will run until June 2028.
Hinshelwood’s previous deal — signed in April last year — was due to expire in June 2026, but the England Under-19 international has now committed his long-term future to the south coast club.
The versatile 18-year-old joined the club aged eight and has made 17 first-team appearances this season.
UEFA 'aware' of alleged IS terror threat, says Champions League matches to take place as planned
UEFA says this week’s Champions League matches are on track to go ahead as planned despite an alleged terror threat made by Islamic State.
The threats, which appear to have come from Islamic State but whose origins are unconfirmed, surfaced as images on social media on Monday evening.
UEFA says it is “aware” of threats and is working with local authorities across Europe. With regards to Arsenal’s game against Bayern Munich at the Emirates Stadium, London’s Metropolitan Police says it will have a “robust policing plan in place”.

Liverpool handed boost as quartet return to training
Liverpool have received a major boost with the return of Trent Alexander-Arnold, Alisson, Diogo Jota and Stefan Bajcetic to team training.
The quartet all took part in Tuesday’s session at Kirkby following extended spells on the sidelines as the focus turned to Thursday’s Europa League quarter-final first leg at home to Atalanta.
Vice-captain Alexander-Arnold hasn’t featured since damaging his knee in early February, while goalkeeper Alisson has missed the past 13 matches in all competitions after tearing his hamstring in training.
Jota has been out for the past two months with a knee injury sustained against Brentford and Bajcetic, who spent last week building up his fitness levels training with the club’s under-21s squad, hasn't played since September due to growing pains.
Murtough leaves Man United
Manchester United have confirmed that John Murtough is to step down from his position as football director.
As reported by The Athletic earlier today, Murtough will leave the club after almost 11 years in a variety of roles.
Co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe said: “We want to thank John for his loyal service over many years, and for his support and integrity during this period of transition. He leaves with our best wishes for the future.”
Co-chairman Joel Glazer said: “After 11 years of tireless work for the club, John has mutually agreed with us that now is the right time to step aside and allow the new football leadership structure to be put in place. He will always be welcome back at Manchester United as a friend of the club.”
Liverpool head of recovery and performance to depart at end of season
Liverpool’s head of recovery and performance Andreas Schlumberger will leave the club at the end of the season.
The 57-year-old, who has been part of the backroom staff since December 2020, will return to his native Germany when the curtain comes down on Jurgen Klopp’s tenure as manager.
Schlumberger was under contract at Liverpool until the summer of 2025 but has reached an agreement with the club to depart in May.
